Context:
George Brown (1818-1880) was a 19th-century Scottish-born Canadian politician and newspaper publisher. He is known for founding The Globe, precursor to The Globe and Mail, and being one of the Fathers of Confederation. In Canada's centennial year, 1967, Bill Davis, then Ontario Minister of Education, suggested naming a new college of applied arts and technology after George Brown.

George Brown College opened in 1968 with just over 2,000 students, offering programs in construction, early childhood education, dental services, culinary arts, signwriting, watchmaking, marine engineering, and more. Since then, the full-time student population has grown to around 30,000.

The college's history can be traced back to the early 1950s with the formation of two provincial organizations: The Department of Education and the Provincial Institute of Trades. In 1964, the Department of Education created the Provincial Institute of Trades and transferred all apprenticeship training from the Ryerson Institute of Technology to it.

The Provincial Institute of Trades opened at 21 Nassau St., in Kensington Market, with Charles Emery as its first principal. Due to a need for more space, two additional buildings were constructed in Kensington Market where students contributed to the construction through field placements. The Provincial Institute of Trades started broadening its program selection by including courses in lathing, structural steel, barbering, diesel mechanics, jewellery arts, watchmaking, and welding. The Provincial Institute of Trades also launched the Provincial Institute of Trades and Occupations to meet the growing demand for vocational training.

Since 2004, George Brown has more than doubled in size and broadened international partnerships while increasing its commitment to strengthening Toronto's cultural, economic, and social fabric.

KEY DATES AND NUMBERS:
- 1818-1880: Birth and death of George Brown
- 1967: Suggestion by Bill Davis to name new college after George Brown
- 1968: Opening of George Brown College with around 2,000 students
- Early 1950s: Formation of The Department of Education and the Provincial Institute of Trades
- 1964: Transfer of apprenticeship training to the Provincial Institute of Trades
- 1968: Opening of George Brown College
- 2004: George Brown more than doubled in size.

Context:
The Institute of Trades launched the Provincial Institute of Trades and Occupations to meet the growing demand for vocational training in the late 1960s. In 1967, Minister of Education Bill Davis established Ontario’s public college system, and George Brown College of Applied Arts and Technology was founded through the amalgamation of the Provincial Institute of Trades and the Provincial Institute of Trades and Occupations. C.C. Lloyd was named the first principal.

George Brown College began operations on March 1, 1967, with 2,009 students and 187 instructors spread across five buildings on two campuses: the Dartnell Campus, near Casa Loma, and the Nassau Street Campus in Kensington Market. Overcrowding was an immediate concern, with some programs forced to run in three shifts from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. The College Street Campus (507 College St.) opened in the late 1960s and George Brown integrated 4,000 students and staff from four Adult Training Centres (ATC). Initially, it offered academic upgrading, commercial courses, the rapidly expanding ESL program, and other vocational training programs such as nursery aid, dressmaking and alterations, pattern making and design, commercial art, signwriting, offset printing, furniture refinishing and repair, retail merchandising, and a large truck driver training program.

In the early 1970s, George Brown added a sprawling new building at 160 Kendal Ave., which was renamed Casa Loma Campus. It offered programs in construction, computer systems and networks, jewellery making, and dance. The campus was originally intended to provide programs with a technology and applied arts focus.

Five hospital nursing schools were merged under the George Brown College umbrella: Toronto General Hospital, St. Michael’s Hospital, St. Joseph’s Hospital, the Atkinson School of Nursing (at Toronto Western Hospital), and Nightingale School of Nursing.

The St. James Campus opened at 200 King St. E. in the late 1960s and integrated George Brown into the fabric of Toronto’s downtown core. It offered programs in business, community services, deaf and deafblind studies, and work/college preparation. The main building was formerly the home of the Christie, Brown and Company Biscuit Factory and later a Hallmark Cards factory.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau visited the Nassau Street Campus in Kensington Market in the late 1960s and greeted students and staff with much media fanfare. The George Brown College Foundation, a separately incorporated registered charity guided by a volunteer board of directors, was established by noted restaurateur John Arena.

Key facts:
- Institute of Trades launched Provincial Institute of Trades and Occupations in the late 1960s
- Minister of Education Bill Davis established George Brown College in 1967
- First principal: C.C. Lloyd
- Operations began on March 1, 1967, with 2,009 students and 187 instructors
- Campuses: Dartnell Campus, Nassau Street Campus, College Street Campus, Casa Loma Campus, St. James Campus
- Overcrowding concern in the late 1960s
- Hospital nursing schools merged under George Brown College umbrella (Toronto General Hospital, St. Michael’s Hospital, St. Joseph’s Hospital, Atkinson School of Nursing, Nightingale School of Nursing)
- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau visited Nassau Street Campus in the late 1960s
- George Brown College Foundation established by noted restaurateur John Arena (no specific year mentioned).

Context:
* George Brown College is a separately incorporated registered charity with a volunteer board of directors, established by John Arena, Doug Light, and Marvin Gerstein.
* George Brown opens one of the first on-site child care centres in a Toronto office building at Waterpark Place. Toronto Mayor Art Eggleton presides over a celebratory balloon release at the office building.
* The Centre for Hospitality and Culinary Arts building opens at St. James Campus. Julia Child spends a day in Toronto signing cookbooks, tasting local foods, and performing a cooking demonstration for culinary students.
* George Brown forms the Sahkitcheway Aboriginal Education Council to guide all aspects of Indigenous education at the college.
* George Brown partners with Ryerson University to offer collaborative programs in areas such as Nursing and Early Childhood Education.
* George Brown becomes one of the first nine Ontario colleges authorized to offer bachelor's degrees.
* Anne Sado becomes the first female president of George Brown College. The Office of Research and Innovation opens to support community and industry problem-solvers.
* The Chefs’ House restaurant opens to the public as part of a major renovation and addition to the Centre for Hospitality and Culinary Arts.
* Sally Horsfall Eaton is named George Brown’s inaugural chancellor – the first chancellor at any Ontario college.
* Waterfront Campus opens as part of the revitalization of the East Bayfront community. The Daphne Cockwell Centre for Health Sciences at Waterfront Campus is home to the Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing and the Schools of Dental Health, Health and Wellness, and Health Services Management.
* George Brown College President Anne Sado is appointed a Member of the Order of Canada by His Excellency the Right Honourable David Johnston for enhancing the role of the college.

Context:
* Honourable David Johnston visited George Brown College to recognize Sado's contributions to enhancing the role of colleges in the education sector and bringing a new vision to George Brown. (no date specified)
* Building Information Modeling (BIM) Lab opened at Casa Loma Campus, enabling digital 3D modeling of buildings for construction-project procurement, building processes, and facility management. (no date specified)
* Green Building Centre opened at Casa Lora Campus, focusing on developing environmentally friendly and energy-efficient construction practices and products. (no date specified)
* Food and beverage research hub launched at 215 King St. E, providing access to advanced learning and applied research spaces, opportunities for product development, prototyping, and commercialization support. (no date specified)
* Fashion Exchange opened in Toronto’s Regent Park neighbourhood, offering training to immigrants and at-risk youth and collaborating with educators, industry, and the community. (no date specified)
* George Brown College's first student residence, The George, opened at Front and Cherry streets. It was previously used as athlete accommodation for the 2015 Pan Am/Parapan Am Games in Toronto. (no date specified)
* Lucie and Thornton Blackburn Conference Centre opened at the residence, honoring the legacy of two runaway slaves who established Toronto’s first cab company, helped found the Little Trinity Anglican Church, and worked on anti-slavery initiatives. (no date specified)
* Prime Minister Justin Trudeau visited Casa Loma Campus, touring BIM facilities and carpentry lab and holding a press conference about the 2017 federal budget. (no date specified)
* Noella Milne was installed as the second chancellor of George Brown College. (no date specified)
* New School of Design opened at Waterfront Campus at Daniels Waterfront—City of the Arts complex at Jarvis Street and Queens Quay East. (no date specified)
* President Anne Sado announced her retirement, effective June 30, 2021, after 17 years of leadership at the college. (date specified: June 30, 2021)
* The COVID-19 pandemic forced shutdowns and other unspecified impacts on the college (no date or details specified).

Context:
George Brown College has been led by its President, Dr. Gervan Fearon, for 17 years as of the publication of this text. The college was forced to close its campuses and suspend classes due to the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020. Virtual delivery of programs began on March 23, 2020, with online and hybrid delivery continuing throughout the Fall 2021 semester.
